instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> got only 1.78V, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi Guys.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no liquid damage.
I know client had fake charger.

Got light on charger but no fan spin.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> got 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> got 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> got 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> got 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> got 0.46V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> got 0.46V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> got only 1.78V

<CHIP>U8030</CHIP> pin 6 which is <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> got 0V.

I I good understand <SIGNAL>PP5V_S</SIGNAL>$ is created by <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/1 @12.5V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/3 @0V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/4 @0V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/5 @0V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>/6-8 @0V

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>/2 @0V
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>/4 @0V
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>/5 @0V
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>/14 @5V
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>/20 @3.34V
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>/21 @3.41V
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>/23 @12.56V

<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> @0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> @0V

I know <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is created by <CHIP>U0500</CHIP>.
Cant find any corrosion on input lines of <CHIP>U0500</CHIP> like <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> etc.

Any idea what next? Is there is chance CPU is fried? Dat have light on USB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> got only 1.78V, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Also check all PCH's RTC signals.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If yes, check if any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signal pulses at least (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> got only 1.78V, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> @3.34V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> @3.1V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> @3.26V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> @3.41V

?<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.?
Yes, there is drop to 0.34V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulse from 0V to 1.1V

RTC signals:
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_PCH_DCPRTC</SIGNAL> 1.58V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> 0.375V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> 2.90V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 2.54V on that line there is <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> which should have 1M resistance but got 0.860M

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> got only 1.78V, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses, all S3 voltages should pulse too, check that.
Change "x" and check the other signals and corresponding voltages enabled.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> got only 1.78V, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
There is pulse on:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>, 
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>,
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL>,
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> very small pulse
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulse
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulse
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> no pulse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> got only 1.78V, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulse"
It controls some S0 voltages; did you check them for pulse?

Check for pulse at pins 1 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
